ccAddLandingHeader: Add your trip for each product
ccSpeciesAndLandingsGuidanceListItem2: Landing dates can be up to {{landingLimitDaysInTheFuture}} days in the future in draft documents but only up to 3 days in the future in final submitted catch certificates
ccSpeciesAndLandingsGuidanceListItem4: Multiple landings can take up to {{offlineValidationTime}} minutes to validate
ccSpeciesAndLandingsGuidanceListItem5: A maximum of {{maxAddLandingsLimit}} landings is allowed per certificate
ccAddLandingStartDateHelpSectionContent: The start date is the date the vessel departed from port to begin the fishing trip during which the catch was made.
ccAddLandingStartDateHelpSectionGuidance: The date the catch was landed (see Date Landed)
The date the catch was sold or processed
ccAddLandingGearDetailsHint: This will be required from January 2026 under EU regulations.
ccAddLandingGearDetailsHelpSectionConten: Gear categories describe the general method used to catch fish, such as trawls or nets.
Gear types are more specific, like "Beam trawls" or "Set gillnets".
Select the most accurate option based on how the fish were caught. If you're unsure, contact your suppliers or fisheries authority.
Find standard gear types and codes on the FAO website (opens in new tab)
ccRfmoHintText: The organisation responsible for managing fishing in the area where the fish were caught
ccRfmoHelpSectionLinkText: What is a regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO)?
ccRfmoHelpSectionContentOne: A regional fisheries management organisation (RFMO) is an international body that manages fish stocks in a specific area of the ocean.
ccRfmoHelpSectionContentTwo: RFMOs are made up of countries that have fishing interests in that region. They work together to:
ccRfmoHelpSectionBulletTwo: set catch limits and conservation rules
ccRfmoHelpSectionContentThree: Some RFMOs focus on specific species, like tuna, while others manage all fish stocks in a region.
ccRfmoHelpSectionContentFour: You only need to select an RFMO if the product was caught in an area covered by one.
ccRfmoHelpSectionContentFive: Find out more about RFMOs on the FAO website (opens in new tab)
eezHintText: The area of sea where the fish were caught
ccEezHelpSectionLinkText: What is an exclusive economic zone (EEZ)?
ccEezHelpSectionContentOne: An exclusive economic zone (EEZ) is a sea area where a country has special rights to explore, manage and use marine resources.
ccEezHelpSectionContentTwo: It starts beyond the countryâ€™s territorial sea (12 nautical miles from the coast) and can extend up to 200 nautical miles.
ccEezHelpSectionContentThree: Within its EEZ, a country can:
ccEezHelpSectionBulletTwo: explore and extract oil, gas and minerals
ccEezHelpSectionBulletThree: generate energy from wind, currents and tides
ccEezHelpSectionContentFour: Other countries can still pass through or fly over the EEZ, but they must respect the laws of the coastal state and international law.
ccEezHelpSectionContentSix: Find maps and codes for EEZs on the FAO website (opens in new tab)
